runs.text: Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that the picture shows crows, which are a type of bird. Have students find the crows in the picture.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means to be willing to share.
with her money and gives it away to charities.
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names what the shiny yellow bead was made of. (gold)
What does Kenzo do that shows he is generous? Find sentences that answer the question.
Could this story happen in real life? Why or why not?
How have you been generous with someone who needed help? What did you do?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that a mountain goat is a special kind of goat that lives high up in the mountains where few other animals can live.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means to change or adjust to what is around you.
Example: A duck has webbed feet that help it
Ask: How do you think a bear might
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that describes the weather in the mountains. (cold)
What body parts have helped the mountain goat adapt to living in the mountains? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why are the mountains a good home for the mountain goat?
What is one thing you think is most interesting about the mountain goat? Why do you think so?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words with long
. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss the different end punctuation for sentences 2 (period), 3 (exclamation point), and 4 (question mark).
Model how you change your intonation when reading a question (raise voice at the end) or exclamation (read with excitement).
Have students echo-read the sentences, replicating your intonation.
Read the title. Explain that these are riddles. A riddle is a tricky word puzzle that you use clues to solve.

For the first reading, have students read the riddle while you read the answer. Then pair students to reread the riddles. Partners can switch roles during the rereadingone reads the riddle while the other supplies the answer.
Prompt students to find all the words with long
spellings in the riddles and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
These supports include the Read/Build/Write routine.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board and have students self-correct. Take note of each students errors on their Student Observation Form.
Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that students will read about goats found in unusual places.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
place for a rabbit to live.
things you have seen? Why were they
Have students whisperread the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names a machine that cuts grass. (lawn mower)
What are some unusual, or strange, places where goats can be found? Find sentences that answer this question.
How are the goats in the city and those in trees alike?
Do you think goats would be happy living by your home? Why or why not?
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words with long
. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss how to chunk sentences into meaningful phrases in order to read them more smoothly.
Explain that good readers look for ways to chunk sentences into smaller parts when they read aloud.
on the train. He kicked one goal
Have students echo-read the sentences and replicate your phrasing.
Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word.

Explain that this text tells about different parts of a goats hoof and how the hooves help the goat climb. It includes two diagrams and callouts. Remind students that authors include diagrams to help readers understand the parts of something important to remember.
Guide students through a reading of the selection, including the diagrams.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the diagrams.

Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the eBook for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read a story about how a lion learns a lesson.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
Ask: What do you picture when you hear the word
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the words that tell what Mouse did that made Lion angry? (woke up)
Do you have to be big to be powerful? Why or why not? Use sentences from the story to answer the question.
The moral of the story is that everyone has value. What does that mean?
What are some ways a person might be powerful?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this is an old story about a king who loved gold. Ask students what they think might happen to a person like this.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means to only care about oneself, and to not share.
boy took all the treats for himself.
Ask: What are some ways a person could be
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question:
What did King Midas love more than anything else? Find the word that answers the question. (gold)
What did King Midas wish for? Find the sentence that answers the question.
What lesson does King Midas learn about being greedy and selfish?
How could you use the lesson from this story in your own life? Give some examples.
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
